questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman comes for a follow-up prenatal visit at 18 weeks' gestation. At 12 weeks' gestation, ultrasonography showed increased nuchal translucency and pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A) was decreased by 2 standard deviations. Chorionic villus sampling showed a 47, XX karyotype. During this visit, ultrasonography shows a hypoplastic nasal bone, shortened femur length, shortened middle phalanges of the fifth digits with clinodactyly. A quadruple marker test would most likely show which of the following sets of findings?



α-Fetoprotein (AFP)
Estriol
β-Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG)
Inhibin A



A
↓
↓
↓
normal


B
↓
↓
↑
↑


C
Normal
normal
normal
normal


D
↓
↓
↓
↓


E
↑
normal
normal
normal
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A decrease in AFP, free estriol, and β-HCG with normal or decreased inhibin A is consistent with trisomy 18 (i.e., Edwards syndrome). While Edwards syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency and decreased PAPP-A during first-trimester screening, as well as a 47, XX karyotype, this patient's shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and hypoplastic nasal bone are indicative of Down syndrome. Ultrasound findings typical of Edwards syndrome include rocker-bottom feet and clenched fists with overlapping of the third and fourth digits by the second and fifth digits, respectively (rather than clinodactyly).

B) CORRECT:

The quadruple screening test is ideally performed between 15 and 22 weeks' gestation and can help to diagnose Down syndrome and other fetal aneuploidies, as well as open neural tube defects. Patients with Down syndrome typically have significantly decreased AFP and free estriol with a marked increase in β-HCG and inhibin A.

C) INCORRECT:

Normal findings in all quadruple screening markers are consistent with a normal fetus, but are concerning for trisomy 13 (i.e., Patau syndrome) in a fetus with a suspected aneuploidy (based on the (47, XX karyotype). While Patau syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency and decreased PAPP-A during first-trimester screening, as well as a 47, XX karyotype, this patient's shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and hypoplastic nasal bone are indicative of Down syndrome. Ultrasound findings suggestive of Patau syndrome include rocker-bottom feet, microcephaly or holoprosencephaly, and polydactyly (rather than clinodactyly).

D) INCORRECT:

A mild decrease in all quadruple screening markers is consistent with Turner syndrome. While Turner syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency (due to lymphatic dysplasia), shortened femur length, and decreased PAPP-A levels, this patient's chorionic villus sampling revealed a 47, XX karyotype, which is not consistent with the 45, XO karyotype that is characteristic of Turner syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

An isolated increase in AFP during pregnancy is characteristic of fetal neural tube defects or open abdominal wall defects such as gastroschisis or omphalocele. While some of these defects (such as omphalocele) may be associated with an increase in nuchal translucency, first-trimester fetal screening would show normal PAPP-A levels and a 46, XX karyotype. Furthermore, none of these conditions would involve shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, or a hypoplastic nasal bone.
questions.hint: Increased nuchal translucency, decreased levels of PAPP-A, shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and a small nasal bone in a fetus with a 47, XX karyotype are features highly suggestive of trisomy 21 (i.e., Down syndrome).

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a 6-week history of fatigue, fever, and recurrent epistaxis. She has a history of duodenal atresia and an atrioventricular septal defect. She is at the 5th percentile for height and 30th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows painless cervical lymphadenopathy. Her hands are short and broad and there is a space between the first and second toes bilaterally. The spleen tip is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. Bone marrow aspirate shows leukocytosis with 50% lymphoblasts. Which of the following best explains this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A frameshift mutation in the X-linked dystrophin gene causes Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), which causes muscle weakness and dilated cardiomyopathy. DMD is not associated with an increased risk of ASD, duodenal atresia, or leukemia. A frameshift mutation is not a mechanism for trisomy 21, which is the most likely cause of this patient's condition.

B) CORRECT:

Meiotic nondisjunction is a pathologic genetic mechanism that can lead to chromosomal aberrations. 95% of cases of trisomy 21 are caused by the meiotic nondisjunction of chromosome 21. In the majority of these cases, this nondisjunction occurs in meiosis I (70%). In 20% of cases, the nondisjunction occurs in meiosis II. In 5% of cases, it is due to paternal non-disjunction during spermatogenesis.

C) INCORRECT:

Deletion of a segment on chromosome 5 can lead to cri-du-chat syndrome. This genetic disease manifests with congenital heart defects (most commonly ventricular septal defect), intellectual disability, facial and skeletal malformations, and, most characteristically, a high-pitched voice. This patient has a history of an ASD, duodenal stenosis, and ALL, which are not typically seen in patients with cri-du-chat syndrome. Deletion of a chromosome segment is not a mechanism for trisomy 21, which is the most likely cause of this patient's condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Uniparental disomy is responsible for 25% of cases of Prader-Willi syndrome and 5% of cases of Angelman syndrome. These syndromes may manifest with short stature, as seen in this patient. However, neither of these conditions is associated with duodenal atresia, ASD, or ALL, and other common manifestations of these syndromes such as obesity, muscular hypotonia, epileptic seizures, and/or behavioral problems are not described in this patient. Uniparental disomy is not a mechanism for trisomy 21, which is the most likely cause of this patient's condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Mosaicism is a genetic condition that can cause trisomy 21. However, it is a very rare cause, accounting for about 1% of cases. Additionally, ALL, duodenal stenosis, and atrioventricular septal defect are less common in mosaic trisomy 21 because not all cells have the characteristic chromosomal aberration, which usually results in less severe symptoms.

Mosaicism is more common (50%) in patients with Turner syndrome, which can cause short stature, specific cardiac defects (e.g., bicuspid aortic valve, aortic coarctation) as well as an increased risk of certain tumors (e.g., cystic hygroma, ovarian gonadoblastoma).

F) INCORRECT:

Trinucleotide repeat expansion is a pathologic mechanism of Friedreich ataxia, fragile X syndrome, and myotonic dystrophy, which are associated with specific cardiac abnormalities (e.g., mitral valve prolapse in Fragile X syndrome, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in Friedreich ataxia, arrhythmias in myotonic dystrophy). None of these conditions are, however, associated with an increased risk of ASD, duodenal atresia, or ALL. Trinucleotide repeat expansion is not a mechanism for trisomy 21, which is the most likely cause of this patient's condition.

G) INCORRECT:

Unbalanced Robertsonian translocation is a genetic variation that involves a translocation (genetics) of the long arms of acrocentric chromosomes, which is one possible genetic change leading to trisomy 21. However, this variation is relatively uncommon and is only found in about 4% of individuals with trisomy 21.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical findings (fatigue, fever, recurrent epistaxis, painless cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly) and laboratory findings (leukocytosis with lymphoblasts) are consistent with acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL). ALL, duodenal atresia, atrioventricular septal defect, short stature, broad hands, and sandal gap are common manifestations of trisomy 21.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old girl with trisomy 21 is brought in for a preparticipation physical before she joins a gymnastics class. She is well and takes no medications. On review of symptoms, she reports occasional neck and back pain while exercising. Her vital signs are normal for her age, as are her cardiac and neurologic examinations. Her parents report that previous cardiac screening, including an echocardiogram, was also normal. Her last routine visit 6 months ago was normal, including recommended screening.
Which one of the following tests, if any, would be most helpful for evaluating this patient before she participates in gymnastics?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) increases the risk for atlantoaxial instability (AAI), which is defined as excessive translation of the C1 vertebra on the C2 vertebra. Although children with trisomy 21 can safely participate in almost any sport, the presence of symptomatic AAI is a contraindication to neck-stressing sports, including gymnastics.

Up to 2% of children with trisomy 21 have symptomatic AAI, and a larger percentage have asymptomatic instability. Current guidelines from the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recommend against routine radiologic evaluation for AAI in asymptomatic individuals, because plain radiographs are not predictive of who will ultimately experience spine problems. Instead, the guidelines recommend routine screening for symptoms that might be due to cord impingement as a result of AAI. In addition, parents should be regularly counseled on the importance of neutral neck positioning for procedures (such as radiologic imaging) and to watch for signs and symptoms of impingement.

This particular patient reports symptoms when exercising (neck and back pain) and should therefore be evaluated for AAI. Any child with new neck pain, weakness, change in tone, gait abnormalities, or change in bowel or bladder function should undergo radiography of the cervical spine in a neutral position. If this image is normal, radiographs in flexion and extension should then be performed.

Key learning point: Patients with trisomy 21 who have neck pain, weakness, changes in tone, gait abnormalities, or changes in bowel or bladder function should undergo cervical spine radiography.

B) INCORRECT:

Complete blood counts are done annually at routine health maintenance visits but are not required specifically for sports clearance.

C) INCORRECT:

Hip radiographs are not indicated for sports participation screening.

D) INCORRECT:

There is an increased risk of low bone density in patients with trisomy 21, but routine screening prior to sports participation is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Although children with trisomy 21 can safely participate in almost any sport, the presence of symptomatic AAI is a contraindication to neck-stressing sports, including gymnastics. This particular patient reports symptoms when exercising (neck and back pain) and should therefore be evaluated for AAI. Any child with new neck pain, weakness, change in tone, gait abnormalities, or change in bowel or bladder function should undergo radiography of the cervical spine in a neutral position. If this image is normal, radiographs in flexion and extension should then be performed.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman and her husband present for preconception planning and counseling. The woman’s sister recently delivered an infant with trisomy 21 (Down syndrome). The couple would like to know what screening tests would be most appropriate for the wife during a future pregnancy. She is otherwise healthy, and she and her husband have no other known personal or family history of genetic disorders.
Which one of the following screening tests will be most appropriate for this couple?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The risk of giving birth to an infant with trisomy 21 increases significantly at age 35. This patient is 36 years old and therefore at high risk for pregnancy complicated by aneuploidy. Noninvasive screening tests for aneuploidy in pregnancy include measurement of maternal serum markers (risk levels are interpreted according to maternal age) and, sometimes, sonographic nuchal translucency (NT) screening.

Of all the standard screening protocols for trisomy 21, the full integrated screen — first-trimester measurement of NT plus serum measurement of pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A and the quadruple screen — has the highest detection rates (94% to 96%, according to data from the FASTER trial). However, a newly validated noninvasive screening test, which involves measuring and sequencing cell-free DNA (cfDNA) in maternal serum, is the most effective method for detecting trisomy 21 in both high- and low-risk obstetric populations (detection rate, 98.6% to 100%). cfDNA testing also has lower false-positive rates than standard screening tests, which may limit the need for invasive diagnostic testing, such as amniocentesis and chorionic villus sampling.

Key learning point: In high-risk pregnant women, the recommended primary screening test for fetal trisomy 21 is a cell-free DNA test.

B) INCORRECT:

Amniocentesis and chorionic villus sampling are reserved for diagnostic confirmation of trisomy 21, given that these tests are associated with a risk of fetal loss (<1% and <2%, respectively). The earliest suggested time for these tests is 15 weeks for amniocentesis and 10 weeks for chorionic villus sampling.

C) INCORRECT:

For patients without access to accurate nuchal translucency (NT) measurement, the serum integrated screen can yield detection rates of 85% to 88%.

D) INCORRECT:

The quadruple screen (maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein, beta-human chorionic gonadotropin, unconjugated estriol, and inhibin A) is an acceptable screening option in the second trimester, but its detection rate is only up to 81%.

E) INCORRECT:

First-trimester NT measurement alone and the second-trimester triple screen (maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein, beta-human chorionic gonadotropin, and unconjugated estriol) have lower detection rates (64%–70% and 69%, respectively, according to the FASTER trial) than the integrated screening test.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old male infant with trisomy 21 presents for a routine visit. His parents report no concerns about feeding, constipation, snoring, breathing, or difficulty hearing.
He has epicanthal folds, upward-slanting palpebral fissures, a small mouth with relative macroglossia, and mild generalized hypotonia. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable.
Thyroid testing, a complete blood count, an echocardiogram, a car-seat test, and a newborn hearing screening were completed soon after birth and were normal. A karyotype confirmed trisomy 21.
Which one of the following tests should be completed when this patient is around 6 months of age?

choices.text: Measurement of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody and total IgA

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cervical spine radiographs are not recommended to screen for atlantoaxial instability in asymptomatic infants with trisomy 21; however, parents should be counseled about the importance of maintaining the spine in neutral positions (avoiding hyperextension) during procedures. Cervical spine radiographs in children under 3 years of age are not accurate because of inadequate mineralization of the vertebrae.

B) INCORRECT:

Measurement of insulin-like growth factor 1 is not routinely recommended for children with trisomy 21.

C) CORRECT:

Infants and children with trisomy 21 are at risk for multiple malformations and genetic conditions, including but not limited to hearing loss, otitis media, vision problems, obstructive sleep apnea, congenital heart disease, thyroid disease, celiac disease, hypotonia, and atlantoaxial instability, as well as anemia and other hematologic problems. Recommendations regarding screening and diagnostic testing for infants and children with trisomy 21 are based on age and symptoms.

At birth, all infants with suspected trisomy 21 should undergo testing and chromosomal analysis to confirm the clinical diagnosis if testing was not done prenatally. Appropriate screening in the neonatal period includes:

• Echocardiography
• Eye examination for cataracts
• Newborn hearing screening using brain-stem auditory evoked response or otoacoustic emissions
• Complete blood count
• Car-seat testing (to evaluate for oxygen desaturation when the infant is in a car seat)
• Thyroid testing (including both free thyroxine and thyroid-stimulating hormone)

During the early months following birth, infants with trisomy 21 and normal screening in the newborn period should be monitored closely for growth and development and any problems, such as otitis media or constipation. Routine testing at 6 months of age should include repeat thyroid testing and a repeat hearing screening.

Infants with trisomy 21 are at risk for both conductive and central hearing loss. A hearing test should be repeated at 6 months of age, 12 months of age, and every 6 months thereafter until normal hearing levels are established by ear-specific testing, usually around age 4. At 6 months, the typical testing is a brain-stem auditory evoked response (BAER). A behavioral audiogram may be attempted at 12 months of age, but many children will not be able to complete the study and may need additional testing by BAER. At that point, annual hearing tests can be performed as long as test results are normal.

In addition, all infants with trisomy 21 should be evaluated by a pediatric ophthalmologist within the first 6 months of life to screen for strabismus, cataracts, and nystagmus.

Key learning point: For infants and children with trisomy 21, screening for hearing loss should be performed at birth and then every 6 months until about age 4, at which point annual testing can be performed.

D) INCORRECT:

Children with trisomy 21 should be screened for symptoms of celiac disease, but testing by measuring tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody and total IgA is only recommended in the setting of symptoms such as diarrhea, protracted constipation, slow growth, anemia, and abdominal pain or bloating.

E) INCORRECT:

A lipid panel is not routinely recommended for children with trisomy 21.

questions.text:
A 6-week-old boy with trisomy 21 is brought in by his mother for reduced feeding frequency, intermittent diaphoresis, and an increased respiratory rate. He has had no fevers, decreases in urine output, or changes in stool output, and there have been no sick contacts.
He was born at full term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. Phenotypical features of trisomy 21 were noted at birth, and the diagnosis was confirmed by a chromosomal karyotype. Despite mild hypotonia, the patient tolerated breastfeeding well and was discharged home on the third day of life. Routine screening at the time, including measurement of oxygen saturation to screen for cyanotic congenital heart disease, was normal.
The patient’s current temperature is 37.6°C, his respiratory rate is 68 breaths per minute, his heart rate is 140 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg, and his oxygen saturation is 94% while he breathes ambient air.
Both lungs are clear to auscultation, but he appears to be in moderate respiratory distress, with intermittent nasal flaring and intercostal retractions. There is a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border with a wide, fixed split second heart sound and an active precordium. Central capillary refill is approximately 3 to 4 seconds. The liver edge is palpable approximately 2 cm below the costal margin. Femoral pulses are 2+ bilaterally. Skin examination reveals no rash. The remainder of the examination is unrevealing.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transposition of the great vessels is a cyanotic congenital heart defect that manifests with significant hypoxemia in the immediate newborn period.

B) INCORRECT:

Although the timing of clinical presentation varies according to the degree of obstruction of pulmonary blood flow, infants with severe right ventricular outflow tract obstruction related to tetralogy of Fallot or isolated pulmonary valve abnormalities typically present with respiratory distress, cyanosis, and hemodynamic instability in the early newborn period after closure of the ductus arteriosus.

C) INCORRECT:

Infants with a large patent ductus arteriosus also may have heart failure symptoms. However, clinical examination generally reveals a continuous machinery murmur, bounding pulses, and widened pulse pressure.

D) CORRECT:

Children with trisomy 21 are at increased risk for congenital heart defects — most commonly, atrioventricular septal defects. Given this increased risk, newborns with trisomy 21 should not only undergo routine screening with pre- and postductal saturations; they should also undergo echocardiography between birth and discharge so that they can be managed proactively.

Infants with atrioventricular septal defects typically present similarly to the infant in the vignette — i.e., with clinical signs and symptoms of heart failure, such as tachypnea, diaphoresis, pallor, and poor feeding. Complete atrioventricular canal defect, which is caused by failed fusion between the superior and inferior endocardial cushions, is characterized by a contiguous atrial and ventricular septal defect and a common atrioventricular valve (tricuspid and mitral valves). It manifests with early and severe heart failure.

A chest radiograph and an electrocardiogram (ECG) are generally part of the initial evaluation of heart failure. Chest radiography often reveals cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary vascular markings. ECG may show various nonspecific findings consistent with the underlying structural and anatomic abnormalities.

Key learning point: Forty to fifty percent of children with trisomy 21 have a congenital heart defect, most commonly an atrioventricular septal defect.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypoplastic left heart syndrome is uniformly fatal in the first few days of life if undiagnosed or left untreated; a child with this diagnosis would not have survived to a 6-week visit.

questions.text:
A 2-day-old female infant with trisomy 21 diagnosed prenatally is ready for discharge. She was delivered vaginally at term with no complications. On day one of life, she underwent echocardiography, which was normal, and she has also had a normal hearing screening; a state newborn screening test has been sent. Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone and free thyroxine levels are normal.
The infant has been breastfeeding well, and her length and weight are at the 25th percentile for her age. She has diffuse hypotonia, epicanthal folds with a flattened nasal bridge, slanted palpebral fissures, and a single transverse palmar crease. The remainder of her examination, including ear, cardiac, lung, and abdominal examinations, is unremarkable.
Which one of the following additional routine tests is indicated for this patient prior to discharge?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Children with trisomy 21 are often at increased risk for iron deficiency because of their diets. Thus, starting at one year of age, they should have their serum ferritin and C-reactive protein (CRP) concentrations measured along with a CBC. Serum ferritin concentration is an accurate measure of iron stores in healthy patients, but ferritin is an acute-phase reactant that becomes elevated in the presence of chronic inflammation or infection; thus, it should be evaluated together with CRP or reticulocyte hemoglobin (CHr) concentration. If the ferritin level is normal but the CRP or CHr concentration is elevated, then the ferritin level cannot be considered a reliable indicator of normal iron status.

B) CORRECT:

All infants with trisomy 21 should have a complete blood count (CBC) with leukocyte differential within the first 3 days of life to evaluate for hematologic abnormalities, including polycythemia and leukocytosis. Ten percent of newborns with trisomy 21 have transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM; formerly referred to as transient myeloproliferative disorder), a transient leukocytosis similar to leukemia in which lymphoblasts are seen in the peripheral smear. This condition occurs during the neonatal period and typically resolves spontaneously after a few months. About 1% of children with trisomy 21 will develop leukemia during their lifetimes, but this proportion is closer to 30% in those who had TAM as infants. All infants with TAM should be evaluated by a hematology-oncology expert. Those with polycythemia should be monitored with regular CBCs until resolution.

If the neonatal CBC is normal, no further testing is needed until one year of age (for screening) unless the patient develops signs of thrombocytopenia or exhibits weight loss, pallor, or fever.

Key learning point: The recommended routine hematologic test to obtain at birth in children with trisomy 21 is a complete blood count with differential.

C) INCORRECT:

Tympanometry is not necessary at this age unless the newborn hearing screening is abnormal and the tympanic membrane is poorly visualized. Repeat hearing screening every 6 months is recommended for children with trisomy 21, so the next hearing screening for this patient will be when she is 6 months old.

D) INCORRECT:

Infants with trisomy 21 and a known cardiac defect should be monitored for signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure. Patients with a normal echocardiogram at birth do not need an electrocardiogram, although they are at increased risk for pulmonary hypertension even if they do not have intracardiac structural defects. Pulmonary hypertension at birth is manifested by acute hypoxemia requiring ventilator support. In older patients with trisomy 21 who have pulmonary hypertension, fatigue and exercise intolerance are more characteristic.

E) INCORRECT:

Children with trisomy 21 have a risk of atlantoaxial instability, but cervical spine radiographs are not recommended in asymptomatic children and would not be helpful before 3 years of age due to immature mineralization of the cervical vertebrae. Even in older children, routine screening is not recommended in the absence of symptoms (such as neck pain, weakness, gait issues, hyperreflexia, or new bladder or bowel incontinence).

questions.text:
A 9-month-old girl with trisomy 21 is brought in to establish primary care after moving from another state. Her karyotype at birth revealed a Robertsonian translocation involving chromosome 21. The parents just learned that the mother (25 years of age) carries a Robertsonian t(14q;21q) translocation, and they would like to know their likelihood of having a second child with trisomy 21.
What is the approximate likelihood that this couple’s next child will have trisomy 21?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

One special case is when the translocation is between the two copies of chromosome 21. Carriers of a balanced t(21q;21q) translocation have no free copies of chromosome 21; consequently, 100% of their viable offspring will have trisomy 21 (the fusion chromosome plus the second parent’s free chromosome 21).

B) INCORRECT:

The risk of having a child with trisomy 21 increases with maternal age and is approximately 1 in 1250, or <0.1%, for the average 25-year-old woman. However, this mother’s risk is higher than average because of the chromosomal translocation she carries and because she already has a child with this condition. For unclear reasons, the risk of recurrence is higher than the baseline risk.

C) INCORRECT:

If one parent is a carrier, three out of the six embryonic chromosomal complements will harbor the Robertsonian translocation (one balanced embryo and two unbalanced), which represents a 50% chance of passing on the translocated chromosome to each embryo, including both balanced and unbalanced offspring. Children who are born with a normal phenotype to a parent carrying a balanced Robertsonian translocation have a 50% chance of carrying the balanced translocation themselves, but they will not have trisomy 21.

D) INCORRECT:

The likelihood of a recessive condition recurring is 25%; however, translocations are not inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.

E) CORRECT:

In most cases of trisomy 21, the individual has three copies of chromosome 21 instead of the usual pair. However, in 3% to 4% of cases, the individual has a Robertsonian translocation, meaning there is an extra (complete or partial) copy of chromosome 21 attached to another chromosome, usually chromosome 14.

Chromosomal translocations can be either balanced (meaning all the chromosomal material is present but rearranged) or unbalanced (meaning there are extra or missing chromosomal pieces). Parents carrying a balanced translocation can have offspring with an unbalanced translocation, and the most common example of this is the Robertsonian t(14q;21q) translocation. Because the very short arms of chromosomes 14 and 21 do not carry critical information, an individual carrying a balanced (14q;21q) translocation is unaffected. He or she has one free copy of each chromosome (14 and 21) in addition to the translocated chromosome. During meiosis, that individual’s gametes can receive the two normal chromosomes (and be normal), the single fusion chromosome (leading to a balanced-translocation carrier), a free chromosome and the fusion chromosome (leading to trisomy 14 or trisomy 21), or just one of the two free chromosomes (leading to monosomy 14 or monosomy 21.)

When an infant with trisomy 21 is found to have a Robertsonian translocation, karyotypes should be obtained for both parents to identify which, if either, is a carrier. Most infants with unbalanced translocations are born to parents who both have a normal karyotype. In this particular case, though, the mother is a carrier of a balanced Robertsonian t(14q;21q) translocation, so there are six theoretical possibilities for the chromosome complement of her embryos: normal, balanced-translocation carrier, trisomy 14, trisomy 21, monosomy 14, and monosomy 21. Given that trisomy 14, monosomy 14, and monosomy 21 are not viable, there are only three truly possible outcomes for her offspring: normal, balanced-translocation carrier, or trisomy 21 —and these three outcomes are not equally likely, given the reduced viability of a fetus with trisomy 21. Thus, her odds of having a second child with trisomy 21 are 10% to 15%. If the father was the carrier of the Robertsonian translocation, the odds would be even lower (2% to 3%).

The risk of trisomy 21 related to a free third chromosome 21 (e.g., not due to a translocation) is 1% to 2%.

Key learning point: When the parents of a child with trisomy 21 wish to determine the likelihood of having a second child with the syndrome, a karyotype of the affected (first) child should be evaluated for translocation of chromosome 21.

questions.text:
A 48-hour-old male infant who is noted on examination to have poor tone, up-slanted palpebral fissures, and a large tongue is being evaluated in the hospital nursery for increasingly frequent and forceful bright-yellow emesis after feeds. His mother reports that he seems uncomfortable during his feeds until he vomits and then he seems hungry again. He passed his first meconium stool several hours ago.
A whole-body radiograph (“babygram”) is obtained (figure).
What is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody and total IgA

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient passed meconium in the first 48 hours of life, which does not preclude a diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease but makes it less likely; therefore, rectal biopsy is not warranted at the present time.

B) INCORRECT:

An abdominal ultrasound would be helpful in an older infant who presents with emesis, to evaluate for pyloric stenosis. This test might also help identify features of malrotation (e.g., reversed position between the superior mesenteric artery and vein), but it would be less sensitive than an upper GI contrast study.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with trisomy 21 should be screened for symptoms of celiac disease (abdominal pain, diarrhea, constipation, and poor growth) at all well-child visits. Celiac disease is an immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by gluten, which is a combination of proteins found in wheat, barley, and rye. A 48-hour-old infant, as presented in this vignette, is unlikely to have had exposure to gluten. Furthermore, vomiting in infancy is not a typical symptom of this condition. Finally, although measuring tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody and total IgA levels is the standard test for celiac disease in patients ≥2 years of age, it is not as reliable a test in children <2 years of age. Therefore, testing for celiac disease in the younger age group should also include deaminated gliadin peptide antibody-IgG.

D) INCORRECT:

Given the increased risk of congenital heart disease in patients with trisomy 21, this patient will require an echocardiogram. However, this evaluation will not help with his current presentation, as his GI symptoms are not likely manifestations of a cardiac condition.

E) CORRECT:

Given his physical findings, this patient most likely has trisomy 21 (Down syndrome), the most common chromosomal abnormality to occur among live births in the United States (1 in 700). Twelve percent of infants with trisomy 21 will have intestinal atresia. This patient’s current gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms are consistent with duodenal atresia, the most common GI anomaly associated with trisomy 21.

Typical signs and symptoms of duodenal atresia include:

• Frequent vomiting, which may or may not be bilious depending on the location of the atresia
• Abdominal distention
• Diminished stool output
• Double-bubble sign on abdominal radiograph (representing distention of the stomach and proximal duodenum, creating the appearance of two bubbles)

When duodenal atresia is suspected, an upper GI contrast study should be performed to exclude malrotation, which is associated both with this condition and with volvulus, requiring emergency surgery.

In addition to duodenal atresia, patients with trisomy 21 are at increased risk for a range of other GI disorders, including both congenital disorders (such as anal stenosis and atresia, esophageal and tracheoesophageal atresia, and Hirschsprung disease) and functional disorders (such as celiac disease, constipation, and gastroesophageal reflux disease).

Key learning point: The most common gastrointestinal malformation associated with trisomy 21 is duodenal atresia.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a mild fever for the past week. He has also had generalized weakness, fatigue, and diffuse pain in his legs and arms for the past month. He has a history of Down syndrome with surgical repair of a congenital atrial septal defect as an infant. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F). Physical examination shows a median sternotomy scar. There are enlarged cervical lymph nodes bilaterally that are nontender to palpation. Otoscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Oropharyngeal examination shows pale lips and a normal palate and tonsils. Results of serum studies show no abnormalities. Results of a complete blood count are shown:


Blood



 Hemoglobin
10.2 g/dL


 Hematocrit
30%


 Leukocyte count

50,000/mm3


 Platelet count
20,000/mm3



Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

EBV serology is used to confirm the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis (IM), which can manifest with fatigue, mild fever, lymphadenopathy, lymphocytosis, and rarely thrombocytopenia and anemia. However, lymphadenopathy is usually tender and accompanied by pharyngitis. Moreover, leukocytosis in IM typically ranges between 10,000–20,000/mm3, and anemia and thrombocytopenia are mild. Marked leukocytosis, anemia, and thrombocytopenia raise suspicion for malignancy.

B) INCORRECT:

Blood culture is the gold standard for diagnosing a systemic infection or bacteremia, which can manifest with protracted fever, general weakness, fatigue, myalgias, leucocytosis, and thrombocytopenia. However, nontender cervical lymphadenopathy is uncommon in systemic infection. Moreover, marked leukocytosis, anemia, and thrombocytopenia raise suspicion for malignancy. While infection should be ruled out in a patient with a hematological malignancy, another test is indicated to confirm the diagnosis of acute leukemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography is used to diagnose infective endocarditis, which can manifest with low-grade fever, fatigue, weakness, myalgias, leukocytosis, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. However, nontender cervical lymphadenopathy is uncommon in infective endocarditis. Moreover, marked leukocytosis, anemia, and thrombocytopenia raise suspicion of malignancy.

D) CORRECT:

Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy are the most appropriate diagnostic tests for acute leukemia, and a finding of ≥ 20% lymphoblasts confirms the diagnosis. A low platelet count is not a contraindication for the procedure and can be managed with a platelet transfusion if necessary. While cell morphology alone can confirm the diagnosis of ALL, additional specialized studies are required for treatment selection. Immunohistochemistry and flow cytometry are used to identify the immunophenotype, including the expression of terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase, and to differentiate between B-ALL and T-ALL. Cytogenetic studies detect chromosomal abnormalities, and molecular testing is typically used to screen for ALL-specific recurrent genetic abnormalities and prognostic markers.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of bone marrow aspirate smear (Wright staining; 1000x magnification)

Intermediate-sized blasts with dispersed chromatin, a moderate amount of cytoplasm, and indistinct nucleoli are seen alongside pale-stained erythrocytes.

These findings are consistent with precursor B-cell ALL.

E) INCORRECT:

A peripheral blood smear is a simple and accessible diagnostic tool that can identify hematological and infectious conditions causing abnormal counts or morphology of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. Although peripheral blood smear can be used to make a preliminary diagnosis of ALL, a different test is the gold standard for diagnostic confirmation.
questions.hint: Down syndrome is an important risk factor for both the lymphoid and myeloid types of acute leukemia. Fatigue and leukocytosis with features of bone marrow failure (e.g., thrombocytopenia, anemia) can occur with both types of acute leukemia, but fever, painful extremities (due to bone pain), and nontender lymphadenopathy suggest acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

questions.text: A 2-week-old girl with Down syndrome presents with tachypnea, poor feeding, and a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Which congenital heart lesion is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is characterized by a continuous, 'machine-like' murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular area. The holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border in this infant does not match the typical auscultatory findings of PDA. Additionally, PDA is more common in preterm infants, whereas this infant's presentation suggests a different congenital heart defect.

B) INCORRECT:

Secundum atrial septal defects (ASDs) are located at the fossa ovalis and typically produce a systolic ejection murmur with fixed splitting of the second heart sound. These defects often remain asymptomatic in neonates, with symptoms appearing later. The holosystolic murmur and early symptoms in this infant suggest a more significant left-to-right shunt, inconsistent with a secundum ASD.

C) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot includes a ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis, leading to a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border. The holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border in this infant suggests a defect with continuous systolic flow, such as a ventricular septal defect. Down syndrome is more commonly associated with atrioventricular septal defects than with Tetralogy of Fallot.

D) CORRECT:

Atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD) is common in patients with Down syndrome due to abnormal development of the endocardial cushions. This defect results in a combined atrial and ventricular septal defect with malformed atrioventricular valves, leading to a left-to-right shunt. The increased pulmonary blood flow manifests as tachypnea and poor feeding in infants. The holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border corresponds to the ventricular component of the defect. Echocardiography is crucial for assessing the defect and planning surgical intervention.

Key learning point: The most common congenital heart defect in Down syndrome is the atrioventricular septal defect, also known as an endocardial cushion defect.

questions.text:
A neonate is born at 37 weeks to a 23-year-old mother following an uncomplicated pregnancy. Birth weight is in the 5th percentile. Examination shows a small neonate with a prominent occiput, clenched hands with overlapping fingers, and rocker-bottom feet. Auscultation reveals a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border.


Heart rate
90/min


Blood pressure
60/40 mm Hg


Which chromosomal abnormality is most likely in this neonate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 13, or Patau syndrome, presents with midline facial anomalies like cleft lip/palate, microphthalmia, and polydactyly. While congenital heart defects occur, the neonate's features, such as a prominent occiput and rocker-bottom feet, are more indicative of trisomy 18. Trisomy 13 often includes holoprosencephaly or scalp defects, which are not mentioned here.

B) INCORRECT:

Down syndrome (trisomy 21) is associated with congenital heart defects but typically presents with features like brachycephaly, flat facies, and a single transverse palmar crease. The neonate's features, such as a prominent occiput and rocker-bottom feet, are more characteristic of trisomy 18. The significant intrauterine growth restriction also aligns more with trisomy 18.

C) CORRECT:

Edward syndrome, or trisomy 18, is characterized by an extra chromosome 18, leading to congenital anomalies such as intrauterine growth restriction, low birth weight, and distinctive physical features. These include a prominent occiput, clenched hands with overlapping fingers, and rocker-bottom feet. Structural cardiac defects are also common, explaining the holosystolic murmur. The combination of these features reflects the developmental disruptions caused by the extra genetic material.

Key learning point: Edward syndrome (Trisomy 18) is characterized by prominent occiput, overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet, and cardiac malformations.

D) INCORRECT:

Turner syndrome (45, X) typically presents with a webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, and lymphedema, along with heart anomalies like coarctation of the aorta. The neonate's features, including a prominent occiput and rocker-bottom feet, do not align with Turner syndrome. The holosystolic murmur suggests a different intracardiac defect.

questions.text: At 18 weeks, a 36-year-old pregnant woman’s quadruple screen shows abnormal levels of maternal serum markers. Which pattern is most consistent with Down syndrome?

choices.text: High maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein, high human chorionic gonadotropin, low estriol, low inhibin A
Low maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein, high human chorionic gonadotropin, low estriol, high inhibin A
Low maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein, low human chorionic gonadotropin, low estriol, low inhibin A
High maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein, low human chorionic gonadotropin, high estriol, low inhibin A

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The typical Down syndrome pattern includes low AFP and estriol, with high hCG and inhibin A. Elevated AFP is linked to neural tube defects, and low inhibin A contradicts the expected increase in Down syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

In Down syndrome (trisomy 21), the quadruple screen typically shows low maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) due to reduced fetal liver production, high human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and inhibin A due to altered placental function, and low estriol from decreased placental synthesis. This pattern reflects the metabolic and hormonal changes associated with trisomy 21, aiding in the identification of pregnancies at increased risk for Down syndrome.

Key learning point: The second-trimester quadruple screen pattern associated with Down syndrome includes high hCG, low MSAFP, low estriol, and high inhibin A.

C) INCORRECT:

While low AFP and estriol can occur in Down syndrome, the condition typically involves elevated hCG and inhibin A due to placental compensation. A profile with all markers low does not align with the characteristic pattern of Down syndrome, which includes increased hCG and inhibin A.

D) INCORRECT:

In Down syndrome, the quadruple screen shows low AFP and estriol, with high hCG and inhibin A. Elevated AFP is more associated with neural tube defects, and low hCG and inhibin A do not fit the typical pattern of Down syndrome.

questions.text:
A term infant is born to a 39-year-old mother with minimal prenatal care. At birth, the infant has upslanting palpebral fissures, a single transverse palmar crease on each hand, and mild hypotonia. A harsh holosystolic murmur is heard along the left sternal border, indicating an endocardial cushion defect. Vitals are stable, and feeding is unremarkable.
Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities most likely explains the clinical findings in this newborn?

choices.text: Nondisjunction leading to an extra chromosome 21
Nondisjunction leading to an extra chromosome 18

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Down syndrome, primarily caused by trisomy 21 due to meiotic nondisjunction, is associated with advanced maternal age. The extra chromosome 21 leads to overexpression of genes, resulting in characteristic features such as upslanting palpebral fissures, a single transverse palmar crease, and hypotonia. The endocardial cushion defect, a common congenital heart defect in Down syndrome, aligns with the clinical findings in this newborn.

Key learning point: The presence of epicanthic folds, flat facial profile, simian palmar creases, and congenital heart defects in a newborn are characteristic features of Down syndrome (Trisomy 21).

B) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) presents with features like micrognathia, low-set ears, and clenched hands, not the upslanting palpebral fissures and single transverse palmar crease seen here. The endocardial cushion defect is not typical of trisomy 18, and the clinical presentation does not align with Edwards syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

A point mutation in FGFR3 causes achondroplasia, characterized by disproportionate short stature and skeletal abnormalities. The features in this infant, such as upslanting palpebral fissures and an endocardial cushion defect, suggest a chromosomal abnormality rather than a single gene mutation like FGFR3.

D) INCORRECT:

Deletion of 22q11 is linked to DiGeorge syndrome, which presents with conotruncal cardiac anomalies, immune deficiency, and hypocalcemia. The facial features and endocardial cushion defect in this infant do not match those of DiGeorge syndrome. Additionally, deletion of 22q11 is not associated with advanced maternal age.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old G2P1 woman presents to the Outpatient Clinic at 17 weeks' gestation for a routine follow-up. She reports no complications in her current pregnancy. Her prenatal labs show increased maternal serum beta-hCG and decreased alpha-fetoprotein and unconjugated estriol. She is concerned about chromosomal abnormalities (see report).
Ultrasound: Appropriate fetal growth with no structural anomalies
Which karyotype is most likely on further diagnostic testing?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The combination of elevated maternal serum beta-hCG and decreased alpha-fetoprotein and unconjugated estriol in the second trimester is indicative of trisomy 21, or Down syndrome. This pattern arises from placental overproduction of hCG and altered fetal protein synthesis due to the chromosomal imbalance. Advanced maternal age increases the risk of nondisjunction, leading to an extra chromosome 21, resulting in the karyotype 47, XX, +21 for a female fetus. Diagnostic procedures like amniocentesis can confirm this chromosomal abnormality.

Key learning point: Elevated hCG levels in the second trimester are a sensitive marker for Down syndrome in prenatal screening.

B) INCORRECT:

A 46, XY karyotype represents a normal male fetus, typically associated with normal maternal serum marker levels. The abnormal pattern of elevated beta-hCG and decreased alpha-fetoprotein and unconjugated estriol suggests a chromosomal abnormality, not a normal karyotype.

C) INCORRECT:

Turner syndrome (45, X) is associated with normal or low beta-hCG and low unconjugated estriol, not elevated beta-hCG. It often presents with structural anomalies like cystic hygroma, which are not observed in this case. The serum marker pattern here is more consistent with another chromosomal abnormality.

D) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 18, or Edwards syndrome, usually presents with decreased beta-hCG, alpha-fetoprotein, and unconjugated estriol. The elevated beta-hCG in this case is inconsistent with trisomy 18. Additionally, trisomy 18 often shows growth restriction and structural anomalies on ultrasound, which are absent here.

questions.text: You are seeing a 45-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 18 weeks' gestation for a prenatal visit. At 12 weeks' gestation, ultrasonography showed a hypoplastic nasal bone. On pelvic examination, the uterus size is consistent with 18 weeks' gestation. Maternal serum studies reveal low α-fetoprotein and free estriol concentrations, with increased inhibin A and β-hCG concentrations. Which one of the following findings is most likely to be observed on physical examination of the infant after delivery?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Meningomyelocele is a neural tube defect associated with folic acid deficiency prior to pregnancy and/or during early fetal development; no association with trisomy 21 exists. In pregnancies affected by neural tube defects, the quadruple test typically shows elevated α-fetoprotein and normal free estriol, inhibin A, and β-hCG concentrations.

B) CORRECT:

A single transverse palmar crease is one of the key dysmorphic features of patients with trisomy 21. Additional findings in the extremities include a large gap between the first and second toes (sandal gap sign), clinodactyly, camptodactyly, and brachydactyly. The likelihood of a trisomy 21 pregnancy rises with advanced maternal age. The incremental risk increases most between 30–40 years of age.

Ultrasonography around 12 weeks' gestation typically shows increased nuchal translucency in addition to the nasal bone hypoplasia identified in this patient.

Key learning point: A single transverse palmar crease is a classic physical finding in infants with trisomy 21 (Down syndrome), often accompanied by other features such as sandal gap toes and hypotonia.

C) INCORRECT:

Ambiguous external genitalia is seen in several disorders of sexual development (DSDs), such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia and placental aromatase deficiency. However, DSDs are not typically associated with specific findings on first-trimester ultrasonography or the quadruple test.

D) INCORRECT:

Microphthalmia is associated with several congenital syndromes, such as trisomy 13, but not trisomy 21. In pregnancies affected by trisomy 13, the quadruple test is typically normal. Ultrasonography around 12 weeks' gestation can show several findings, including nasal bone hypoplasia (as seen in this patient) and skeletal defects, such as polydactyly.

E) INCORRECT:

Clenched fists with overlapping fingers (the index finger over the third finger and the fifth finger over the fourth) are associated with trisomy 18, but not trisomy 21. In pregnancies affected by trisomy 18, the quadruple test typically shows decreased concentrations of α-fetoprotein, free estriol, and β-hCG, and a normal or decreased concentration of inhibin A. Although ultrasonography around 12 weeks' gestation may show several findings, including clenched fists with overlapping fingers, nasal bone hypoplasia would be uncommon.
questions.hint: First-trimester ultrasonography that shows nasal bone hypoplasia, in combination with a second-trimester quadruple test with the given biochemical profile, is highly suggestive of trisomy 21 in the fetus.

questions.text: You are seeing a 44-year-old man who is brought to your clinic by his father because of progressive forgetfulness and social withdrawal over the past year. He has increasing difficulty remembering names of acquaintances and now requires more assistance with dressing, cooking, and personal hygiene. He was diagnosed with a genetic disorder in infancy. On physical examination, he has prominent epicanthal folds, low-set small ears, and a protruding tongue. Mental status examination reveals significant deficits in both short- and long-term memory. Which one of the following neuropathologic changes is most likely responsible for his cognitive symptoms?

choices.text: Synaptic build-up of abnormal prion protein.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Synaptic build-up of abnormal prion protein causes prion diseases, such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, which is characterized by rapidly deteriorating cognitive function and myoclonus provoked by startle. Even though this patient has dementia, the protracted course of his illness favors another diagnosis. Moreover, trisomy 21 is not a risk factor for prion diseases.

B) CORRECT:

Accumulation of extracellular amyloid plaques and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles are observed in Alzheimer disease (AD). A majority of patients with trisomy 21 develop early-onset AD since an extra copy of the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene (located on chromosome 21) leads to higher absolute levels of APP expression and deposition of the encoded amyloid-beta peptide in the brain as well as the cerebral vasculature. Mutations in the APP gene are associated with early-onset familial AD.

Key learning point: Individuals with trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) are at increased risk for early-onset Alzheimer disease due to accumulation of extracellular amyloid plaques from overexpression of the amyloid precursor protein gene on chromosome 21.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cerebral cortical tissue (H&E stain and anti-amyloid beta precursor protein immunostaining)

Multiple large red-brown extracellular structures are visible within the cortical matter. These are beta-amyloid plaques that have taken up the immunostain.

Accumulation of amyloid plaques in the interneuronal spaces of the brain is a characteristic feature of Alzheimer disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Cytoplasmic inclusions of ubiquitinated TDP-43 are observed in one of the pathologic variants of the frontotemporal dementia (FTD) clinical spectrum, FTLD-TDP. FTD manifests in middle-aged individuals; however, unlike with this patient, memory and orientation are initially preserved and early symptoms include changes to personality and social behavior. Moreover, trisomy 21 is not a risk factor for FTD.

D) INCORRECT:

Intracellular aggregations of alpha-synuclein (Lewy bodies) are observed in Lewy body dementia and Parkinson disease; neither condition is associated with trisomy 21. Unlike this patient, who presents with early memory impairment, patients with Lewy body dementia show early impairment of attention, visuospatial, and executive functions. Moreover, Lewy body dementia is usually associated with other findings, such as visual hallucinations, movement disorders, dysautonomia, and sleep disorders.

E) INCORRECT:

Multifocal deposition of excess copper in the lentiform nucleus, liver, and other organs has been observed in Wilson disease, which is caused by impaired hepatocellular copper transport due to ATP7B gene mutation. Wilson disease typically manifests with liver disease, movement disorder, and psychiatric manifestations before the age of 35. None of these features are present in this patient.
questions.hint: Prominent epicanthal folds, low-set small ears, and a protruding tongue are signs of trisomy 21. This patient's presentation of cognitive and memory impairments is consistent with a condition that manifests early in patients with this genetic disorder.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the physician by his father. Over the past year, the patient has become progressively forgetful and withdrawn. He frequently has trouble remembering names of acquaintances, and has been requiring increasing amounts of assistance with getting dressed, cooking, and personal hygiene. He was diagnosed with a genetic disorder during infancy. Physical examination shows prominent epicanthal folds, low-set small ears, and a protruding tongue. Image Description:

Microscopy of the substantia nigra of a patient with Parkinson disease (upper row: 60x magnification, lower row: 20x magnification; staining with antibodies against alpha-synuclein, counterstaining with Mayer hematoxylin)

Both Lewy bodies (spherical intracytoplasmic aggregates of alpha-synuclein; green overlay) and the strand-like Lewy neurites (neurites containing alpha-synuclein aggregates; white arrows) are visible.

Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cortical brain tissue (H&E stain)

The tissue shows spongiform degeneration, which is the result of neuronal loss and the formation of numerous vacuoles of varying size (green overlay).

This is the characteristic histopathological appearance of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (detection of prions is only possible via immunohistochemistry).

Mutations in the APP gene are associated with early-onset familial AD.

Photomicrograph of cerebral cortical tissue (H&E stain and anti-amyloid beta precursor protein immunostaining)

Multiple large red-brown extracellular structures are visible within the cortical matter. These are beta-amyloid plaques that have taken up the immunostain.

Accumulation of amyloid plaques in the interneuronal spaces of the brain is a characteristic feature of Alzheimer disease.
